body: To the Editor: You report that corrosion threatens New York City's bridges, including three that span the East River (news article, Dec. 17). This sounds like the old refrain: city and state officials continue to fiddle while our vital transportation system burns. The solution does not lie in debating why or how the bridges deteriorated, but in
title: Williamsburg Bridge Must Be Rebuilt

body: A 31-year-old immigrant from Ethiopia with a load of Christmas packages was shot and killed in the driveway of his house in Far Rockaway, Queens, on Christmas Eve, the police said yesterday. The man, Berhane Waldermarian, was one of at least 10 New Yorkers killed in separate incidents on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. Among them were a Bronx baby
title: Ethiopian Immigrant Carrying Christmas Gifts Is Slain in Queens

title: 10 Detectives Face an Inquiry On False Data

body: The strike this week by 2,100 private sanitation workers is the latest shock wave from a little-publicized decision by New York City two years ago to prolong the use of its biggest garbage dump. The decision was to more than double the price the city charged private haulers to dump garbage at the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island. That set off
title: How a Small Policy Change Led to a Big Garbage Strike

body: The Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps officially began on Feb. 23, 1989. Within 24 hours, its president, James Robinson, and a colleague spotted a fire in an abandoned building and saved 10 people. Within 48 hours, volunteers had delivered a baby. The pace never slackened. Drug-related violence devastates this poor Brooklyn neighborhood.
title: About New York; Bed-Stuy, Do or Die. For Real. 911.

body: The owner of a Brooklyn restaurant was shot to death yesterday afternoon by police officers when he refused to drop a sawed-off shotgun that he had pointed at the officers in his restaurant, the police said. title: Armed Restaurateur Shot to Death by Police

body: LEAD: Brooklyn has long been a major site of that essential art-world ritual, the studio visit, the pilgrimage that dealers, critics and collectors make to encounter artworks and artists in their natural habitats. title: Pop/Jazz; Tomorrow's Stars Today In Brooklyn's Small Clubs
